title: 108_hr1618
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act". The Arabia Mountain area contains diverse natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources that represent the heritage of the United States. Management through partnerships between public and private entities is recommended. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in Georgia protects various ecosystems and federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain is a national natural landmark. Panola Mountain, located in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park, is a rare granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve shows evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain display the history of granite mining. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation. Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The goal is to preserve and promote natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other sites. Assistance is provided to develop and implement a management program to protect and interpret these resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

    Definitions for the Act:
        - Heritage area: Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area
        - Management entity: Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance or successor
        - Management plan: Plan for the heritage area
        - Secretary: Secretary of the Interior
        - State: State of Georgia

SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA is established in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is the management entity. The map is available for public inspection. The management entity for ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA in Georgia may make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts for goods and services. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests within the heritage area and gives priority to certain tasks. The management entity for ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA in Georgia must prioritize actions from the management plan, hold quarterly public meetings, submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments and finances, and allow audits by the Secretary. The management entity for ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA in Georgia must provide records for audit of Federal funds and agreements, and cannot use Federal funds for acquiring real property. They can use funds from other Federal laws for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the feasibility study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources in the area. The management plan for the heritage area should include a list of significant properties to be preserved, an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation involving various entities. The management plan for the heritage area should include a list of significant properties to be preserved, an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, a program for implementation involving various entities, government, private organizations, and public-private partnerships to protect resources, identification of funding sources, and description and evaluation of the management entity. The management entity must submit the plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding under the Act. The management plan for the heritage area must be submitted to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to do so will halt additional funding under the Act. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days, providing recommendations for revisions if needed. After approval of the management plan, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the plan to the Secretary for approval within 90 days. The management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the plan to the Secretary for approval within 90 days. No funds shall be used to implement any proposed revisions until approved by the Secretary. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE: The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. SEC. 8. EFFECT ON CERTAIN AUTHORITY. The Act does not impose stricter regulations on occupational, safety, conservation, or environmental aspects within the heritage area than those applicable to the land before its establishment. It also does not authorize federal agencies to enforce stricter regulations solely due to the heritage area's creation. The Act does not change existing land use regulations or grant zoning powers to the management entity. SEC. 9. REQUIREMENTS FOR INCLUSION OF PRIVATE PROPERTY. Private property in the Heritage Area requires notification and consent from owners for preservation, conservation, or promotion by the management entity. Landowners can request removal of their property from the boundary. SEC. 10. PRIVATE PROPERTY PROTECTION. (a) Access to Private Property.--This Act does not require private property owners to allow public access or modify any laws regarding public access to private property. 
(b) Liability.--Designation of the Heritage Area does not create liability for property owners for injuries on their property. 
(c) Recognition of Authority To Control Land Use.--This Act does not change the authority of governments to regulate land use. 
(d) Participation of Private Property Owners in Heritage Area.--Owners are not required to participate in the Heritage Area. The establishment of the Heritage Area boundaries allows for the use of Federal funds within that area, but does not grant any new regulatory authority over land use to the Secretary, National Park Service, or management entity. Owners of private property within the Heritage Area are not required to participate in or be associated with it. SEC. 11. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 authorized for this Act, with $1,000,000 limit per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50% of project cost. 

SEC. 12. Termination of Authority: Secretary's grant and assistance authority under this Act ends on September 30, 2016.
